XWP v XWQ

XWP v XWQ
[2025] SGFC 140

Case Number:Divorce No 5053 of 2022, Summons 1794 and 2035/2024, HCF/DCA 121/2025
Decision Date:09 January 2026
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Shobha Nair
Counsel Name(s): Plaintiff in person; Audrey Liaw Shu Juan (PY Legal LLC) for the Defendant
Parties: XWP — XWQ

Family Law – Custody, care and control of child – Variation of consent order

9 January 2026

District Judge Shobha Nair:

Introduction

1       The plaintiff (husband/father) and defendant (wife/mother) were married in September 2009 and have a daughter who turned 7 years of age in 2025. An Interim Judgement (IJ) was issued in 2022 dissolving the marriage. After what appears to be significant attempts at mediation, the parties agreed on the care arrangements for their daughter which is reflected in a consent order dated 3 April 2023. The daughter was 5 years old at the time. In 2024, both parties sought variation of the consent order, principally as it relates to issues of custody, care and control of their child. Having heard from the parties and having had the opportunity to speak with the child, I found no reason to change the terms of the order and accordingly dismissed the applications save that I no longer felt it necessary that the husband place a deposit of S$20 000 with his solicitors each time he takes his child overseas nor the need for the wife to retain all of the child’s passports. The wife appeals against all orders.

Background

2       The husband is 60 years of age, a permanent resident in Singapore[note: 1] and was at the time of the applications before me, retrenched from his position as a Director of Accounting for Sustainability at a company providing workforce solutions. He has since taken on an adjunct teaching position at a local university. He shared that with the income he receives from teaching, his savings and inheritance received from his late father, he is financially stable and does not at this time of his life need to take on another job. The wife is 50 years old and a Singaporean. She works part-time as a lecturer at a local polytechnic.

3       The parties were blessed with a child after 8 years of marriage and both agreed that they were equal partners in the care of their daughter in the early years of the child’s life. The marriage faced difficulties and in 2021 the husband left the home. They were living with the wife’s parents at that time. He filed for divorce in 2022. Through a series of mediation sessions, the parties agreed to the following:

Order of Court dated 3/4/2023

1.     Parties shall have joint custody of the only child of the marriage.

2.     Parties shall have shared care and control of the child as follows:

(a)        Until August 2024, the father shall have care of the child on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays from 11 a.m. to Monday (when the child is dropped off at school);

(b)       The mother shall have care of the child for the remaining period of the week;

(c)       The father shall have liberty to travel with the child for 18 days in July 2023, 2 weeks in February/early March 2024 (after Lunar New Year) and 3 weeks in July 2024;

(d)        From August 2024, the father shall have care and control of the child from Saturdays at 2 p.m. to Tuesday mornings when she is dropped off at school;

(e)       The mother shall have care of the daughter for the remaining period of the week;

(f)       The parties agree to attend co-parenting counselling after the date of this Order with the child or any other independent counsellor mutually agreed upon between the parties. The parties shall attend the co-parenting counselling once a month, commencing within one (1) month from the date of this Order. Further, parties shall share the costs of the co-parenting counselling equally; and

(g)       The child’s school holidays shall be split equally between the parties, with parties having the liberty to bring the child overseas during their respective shares of the school holidays.

3.     There will be no make-up access should either party miss their time with their child.

4.     Unless mutually agreed between the parties, neither party shall enlist the assistance of non-family members to care for the child during their time with her and neither party shall place the child ins afterschool care.

5.     Where either party travels overseas with the child, the travelling party shall provide the non-travelling party with prior notice of at least one (1) month, and shall also provide the non-travelling party details of the trip, including but not limited to flights, itinerary and contact details. The plaintiff shall deposit S$20 000 to his solicitors’ firm to hold as stakeholders, at least seven (7) days prior to his overseas travels with the child, upon which the defendant shall release the child’s passports to the plaintiff in accordance with Clause 9 below;

6.     Parties agree that the child shall continue to be enrolled at the XXX pre-school and thereafter she shall be enrolled at a local school;

7.     The father shall register the child ay the German Embassy before the end of 2023 and the mother shall do the necessary to facilitate and consent to the same including attending at the Embassy together with the plaintiff to attend to the application;

8.     The father shall apply for Swiss and German passports for the child before the end of 2023, and the mother shall do the necessary to facilitate and consent to the same including attending at the Embassy together with the plaintiff to attend to the application;

9.     All of the child’s passports shall be retained by the mother. The defendant shall release the child’s Singapore passport to the plaintiff at least 7 days prior to the father’s intended travel overseas with the child. The father shall return the child’s passport to the defendant within seven (7) days of his return to Singapore, upon which the father’s solicitors may release the deposit of S$20 000 to him; and

10.     The parties agree that they shall respond within four (4) hours for urgent communication from the other party and within twenty-four (24) hours for non-urgent communications from the other party.

The present appeal

4       In summons 1749/2024, the wife sought the sole custody, care and control of the child, offering the husband access every Saturday afternoon to Sunday evening. She asked that reasonable access be given to the child’s father on school holidays, on dates to be mutually agreed and subject to the child’s school and co-curricular activities. She also agreed that the father should have the liberty to take the child on holidays overseas. In summons 2035/2024, which was the husband’s application for variation of the consent order, he too sought sole custody, care and control of the child and offered access to the mother on weekends and an additional day in the school week. The wife claimed that the husband filed his application only in “retaliation” to the wife’s application. The husband on the other hand, alleged that the wife was unhappy that maintenance for the child was not increased when they were before a different court on account of the shared care and control arrangement. Nothing turned in my view, on the allegations by each party on the motivations of the other. The husband also sought a rescission of the order requiring S$20 000 to be placed as a deposit each time he travels with the child and that he be permitted to retain the German and Swiss passports for the child when these are issued.

5       On receipt of my orders, the wife’s counsel sought further arguments on 4 August 2024 in relation to the ability of the husband to retain the Swiss and German passports of the child once these were issued. Counsel sought to present these further arguments largely on the basis that the court ought not to have interfered with some parts of a consent order while retaining others. I declined to hear further arguments and the wife’s counsel appealed against all the orders, including the order rescinding the need for S$20 000 to be deposited with the husband’s solicitors when he travelled with the child. Given that the appeal was filed out of time, counsel sought an extension of time which was granted.

Variation of the Consent Order

6       Section 128 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (2020 Rev Ed) allows a court to vary an order for the custody, care and control of children where it is satisfied that the order was based on any misrepresentation or mistake of fact or where there has been any material change in circumstances. S 129 of the Charter allows for the variation of terms that were agreed to between parties regardless of when the agreement was made and despite any provision to the contrary in that agreement where it is satisfied that it is reasonable and for the welfare of the child to do so. In this regard, the words of the court in VWQ v VWR[note: 2] are instructive when it said that “Generally, a consent order is a contract negotiated and agreed upon by parties, and the courts would be slow to re-write their contract. Privately settled terms negotiated by the parties, especially in family matters are to be encouraged. As such, they should be respected and not lightly changed. Otherwise, one party may lead the other to believe that obtaining a consent order would end their dispute, only to call in aid, the provisions in the Women’s Charter to vary their agreement when they feel that the bargain was not to their liking subsequently”.[note: 3]

7       Both parties rooted their arguments largely on there being a material change in circumstances since the consent order was issued in April 2023 and/or its unworkability. If anything, the changes in circumstance were of a nature which called for the retention of the consent order save for the need to relook the issue of conditions imposed in relation to overseas travel.

Custody of the child

8       The wife wanted the joint custody order to be varied to one that allows her to have sole custody. The main reason appears to be that the parties have different parenting styles and there was an inability to communicate effectively on matters which involve the child. The court in VRJ v VKR[note: 4] quoting the words of the court in CX v CY[note: 5] two decades ago, and emphasising its continued relevance today said “The court grants sole custody only in exceptional circumstances, such as where one parent physically, sexually or emotionally abuses the child or where the parties’ relationship is such that co-operation is impossible even after mediation and counselling avenues are explored and this lack of co-operation is harmful to the child”.[note: 6]

9       Often marriages come to an end because of unmet expectations, an inability to communicate effectively or different parenting styles which may lead to constant conflict. These cannot be reasons for sole custody orders unless the nature of these challenges bear on the welfare of the child. If it were otherwise, most parents and in particular fathers of young children, may see their rights and responsibilities limited. This will invariably affect a child who has benefitted from the presence and involvement of both parents when times were better. When parties separate, the need for co-parenting becomes an imperative as the child who suddenly finds himself without one parent in the home should not have to accept the absence of that parent in decisions which affect him. Save for situations where one parent is intentionally disrupting decision-making, there is no reason to remove a parent from his or her varied roles as protector, provider, decision-maker and supporter. When there is a divorce between a husband and wife, it must never result in a divorce between parent and child which a sole custody order effectively signifies. Sole custody orders should only be issued in cases where the facts clearly support the preservation and enhancement of the child’s welfare from such an order. Counsel for the wife relied on the cases of Soon Peck Wah v Woon Che Chye[note: 7] which defines child welfare and AZB v AZC[note: 8] where the court stated that a principled and pragmatic approach should be taken in determining material changes in circumstances. I was mindful of the court’s guidance in the cases cited as I approached the facts of the present case.

10     One of the key examples the wife chose to highlight in order to show that parenting styles were vastly different was in the training of the child to use the toilet. The child today is 7 years of age, and this example even if viewed as something of significance, is no longer relevant. Another concern raised was that the husband would sign his daughter up for classes without informing the wife.[note: 9] While clearly there needs to be communication between the parties on what the child’s activities are or should be, the fact that the husband was willing to take the child for these activities when she was with him and pay for these classes reflects his interest in exposing the child to activities beyond academic pursuits. Different parenting styles stem from differences in the backgrounds of the parents and what they were exposed to, growing up. The question is not whether the styles are different but whether exposure to different styles is harmful to the child. The child clearly will not be hurt by swimming classes and exposure to different languages.[note: 10] There is of course the danger that too many classes may result in the child having little time to rest or prioritise school demands. However, there was no indication of that and these matters must be left to the parents to work through. Both parents would want the child to thrive and they both show a resolve to maximise her potential.

11     The wife narrated an incident which she submitted was an example of a lack of communication between parties. This related to a time when the husband returned from an overseas trip with his daughter in March 2024. The husband was alleged to have ignored calls from the wife and it was only 3 hours later that the wife found the child at her father’s house. The wife speaks of how the child was “teary eyed” when the wife saw her and that she “….had to assure [the child] that she could stay with the plaintiff if she wanted to”.[note: 11] While the husband must certainly communicate with the wife who was anxious about the safe return of her child, I could not conclude that he had failed to do so intentionally. What perhaps is more telling is the response of the child. She wanted to stay on with her father and the mother ended up having to reassure her that she could. While it is always more convenient to parent alone after a divorce, it is almost always not the right way forward for the child. In the present case, the involvement of the father in all areas of the child’s life can only enhance her well being. He is able to guide her in her academic life, has the tools to help her regulate her emotions well[note: 12] and exposes her to the richness of cultures through the diversity of the larger family, on both sides. A court should not interrupt this. The wife in applying for variation of the consent order sought that reasonable access be given to the husband on dates to be mutually agreed. The fact that she felt that they could agree on the dates suggests I would have to assume, that she has no issue communicating with the husband. Even if she spoke of the resistance of the father to her choice of primary school for the child, the fact is that the child has been enrolled in the primary school that the mother wished for. Continued co-parenting can work in this case and would certainly send the right signal to the child of the love and care of both her parents. As a child without siblings and the absence of support from the larger family on her father’s side in Singapore, it would do little for the welfare of this child to reduce the support of her father.

12     The wife also pointed to the fact that the husband travels extensively as a further reason for a change in the current arrangement. However by the time of the hearing, the husband no longer was in a work capacity that required regular travel and informed that he was not intending to take on work which would require it. The wife pointed to a specific incident in the past where the husband had to engage the help of a cousin’s daughter who flew in from Germany to care for the child when he had to travel. The reason for having done it was because the wife refused to care for the child during his period of absence from Singapore. The wife said “However, sometime in November to December 2023, the plaintiff was, again, required to travel overseas for work. By that time, I had already been frustrated with the frequency of work trips that the plaintiff had been taking and for which I have to cover for him. I was reluctant to cover for the plaintiff yet again as I did not want the plainiff to form the habit in assuming that I was always available to cover for him.”[note: 13] In the context of a marriage, where one spouse has to travel for work, the other continues to care for the children. It should not have to be different in the context of divorce. The husband was not intentionally taking on travel. He was not using it as an excuse to avoid being present. He chose a relative from Germany simply because the order prohibits a non-family member from being tasked. The reluctance of the wife to step in was also troubling and further entrenches the idea that she was happy to have the child with her father.

Care and Control of the child

13     At the time the consent order was made and shared care and control of the child was agreed on, the child was in preschool. The wife seeks for care and control with access to the husband from Saturday afternoon to Sunday evening every week. She speaks of the unworkability of the order for shared care and control. She also spoke of how the child was stressed having to shuttle between homes and the lack of co-operation on the part of the husband resulting in the child trying to meet the expectations of both parties as a result of different parenting styles.[note: 14] Acrimony is indeed a relevant factor in any analysis of whether shared care and control would be in the child’s interest.[note: 15]

14     The wife emphasised that the child suffered from night terrors and insomnia. She also attributed the onset of facial tics which the child appeared to have experienced, to the fact that the husband told the child to keep secret, the plans and activities the child had with him. The wife also pointed to the transition between the two homes and school as distressing for the child and that she was not “carefree” because she would be wondering who would be picking her up from a school on any given day. The wife further spoke of the child having dyspnoea (shortness of breath) which she said the husband downplayed. The wife essentially was seeking care and control on the basis that this would provide the child with security, stability and certainty.[note: 16] The child having started primary school is an important factor when considering the need to have her under the care and control of one parent. It clearly is more convenient. In my view however, the present shared care arrangements served the child better and should not be disrupted.

(a)     I met with the child together with a court psychologist on 25 June 2025. It was an opportunity and privilege to understand her feelings and to learn directly from her, how she sees herself, her parents and her life in school. She loves her parents and like most children, wants to ensure that they are not disappointed in her. She wants to be with both in the same home and is understandably sad that this is not possible. She did not find it difficult to travel from one home to school on a few days of the week and from another home to school on the remaining days. The difference in travel time between the mother’s residence to and from school and that of her father’s home to and from school, is negligible. As the husband put it, ‘10 versus 15 minutes” does not make much of a difference.[note: 17] The father has put in place a pattern where the child is fed well and cared for. So too has her mother. The child is in lower primary school and school demands are not such that she would be burdened from having to be in two different homes over the week. In XCQ v XCP[note: 18] the need for “constancy and consistency” was the basis on which the court varied a shared care and control arrangement. It is my view that these are the very reasons to keep the shared care and control in place in the present case. The child is familiar with the routine, feels comfortable with it, enjoys her time with both parents and she does not have to travel long distances after school to the different homes.

(b)     In Singapore, where distances between places are not large and where children often spend time in the homes of grandparents, uncles, aunts or in student care centres as they wait to be picked up by parents daily or even weekly, the wife should feel confident that separate homes in and of itself do not go against the interests of a child. The nature of the arrangements is what one needs to be concerned about. Clearly in some cases, shared care and control does not work for the child. The parents here however are available and accessible to the child, take the effort to pick her up and drop her off at school, communicate with her teachers, tutor if needed, and are attentive to her physical and emotional needs as seen in the engagement of the child psychologist by the father to address the child’s night terrors.[note: 19] The child is familiar and happy with the arrangements and it affords the father time to nurture the relationship. It should not be a court that displaces the potential for a strong and supportive father-child relationship even as the child continues to grow well under the guidance and love of her mother.

(c)     The husband has a lot more time today that he has stopped full-time work and can afford the attention that the child needs. There is no longer a need to travel overseas for work. The concerns that the mother has with respect to the child’s night terrors, insomnia and facial tics which she attributes to the need to move from one house to another is not borne out by the evidence. These incidents were when parties started to live apart and when the child was in preschool and she may have been stressed and anxious. The events however, occurred largely in 2023 and 2024. When I met her in the middle of 2025, she spoke of how she was doing much better. We had a very good conversation. If the parents co-operate, she is likely to do even better. The child needs time, space and peace to grow well. Only the parents can help her do that. The first step would be to communicate reasonably well with each other and compromise on issues that are close to the hearts of each parent. Importantly, allow the child to witness those efforts. When a parent is happy, a child often is too.

Termination of the need for a deposit and the retention of the passports by one parent

15     The need for the father to deposit a sum of S$20 000 each time he travels with his child was not in my view a condition that should be kept in force. The husband was no longer represented by his legal counsel and it is unnecessary to retain it. If it was intended to secure the return of the child, it is of little value. The husband has been permitted to take the child overseas. In fact, the mother had repeatedly shown that she had no real concerns about the child being with her father. S$ 20 000 would not serve to deter a man who intends to keep his child away from Singapore and her mother. It cannot in my view be fair to impose conditions such as this everytime a Singaporean marries a foreigner. There is nothing in the past conduct of the husband to suggest that he would not return to Singapore. He has travelled with his daughter many times and his return to Singapore was not on account of the deposit that he wanted to have back. Agreeing to such a term may have been to provide some assurance to the mother initially but it cannot be for the long term.

16     Even though the consent order provides for the wife to hand the child’s passport to the husband when he wants to travel with her, the wife had not done so at the time of the hearing for an intended trip during the school holidays. The wife’s counsel said that this was because the wife wanted the return of the child’s birth certificate held by the husband.[note: 20] There is additionally the need for the wife to facilitate the issuance of the German and Swiss passports which was at the time of the hearing, still outstanding. There is no good reason for all the passports to be retained by the wife. I ordered that when the German and Swiss passports are issued, the husband is to keep them while the wife retains the Singapore passport. This is in keeping with the nature of the shared arrangements in place. The child is a child of parents from different cultures. The fear of a mother that her child would not return to Singapore if the father has access to passports can be appreciated, but there is no evidence to support this fear. If a court were to issue orders to mitigate the possibility of abduction, it must be because the evidence shows a real risk. In this case it does not. Both Germany and Switzerland are parties to the 1980 Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction and swift action can be taken against the husband who risks losing all contact with his child should he attempt to take the child out of Singapore without permission.

Conclusion

17     There was no need to vary the consent order as it relates to the child’s custody, care and control. She is thriving under the current arrangements and the father is more available to her now than when the consent order was made. The concerns with night terrors and insomnia appear symptomatic of a child caught in between parents she loves and would rather that they remained together. With time, a new and healthy norm has come about and she is doing much better today. As the child grows and school demands become greater, there may be a need to relook the terms. For now, it is important not to fix things which are not broken. The workability of the order is contingent on how the parties conduct themselves. Open communication and a resolve to put the child first will produce good results for the family as a whole. Insofar as overseas travel conditions are concerned, the futility of placing a deposit with a counsel the husband no longer has and allowing the wife to be the custodian of all the child’s passports despite a shared care arrangement, logically and fairly called for a rescission of those orders.

XYD v XYE

XYD v XYE
[2026] SGFC 8

Case Number:SSP 1284/2025
Decision Date:13 January 2026
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): The Applicant in-person and unrepresented; The Respondent in-person and unrepresented.
Parties: XYD — XYE

Family Law – Family Violence

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

Family Law – Domestic Exclusion Order

Family Law – Stay Away Order

Family Law – No Contact Order

Family Law – Mandatory Treatment Order

13 January 2026

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       SSP 1284 of 2025 (“SSP 1284”) was the Wife’s application for a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”) against her Husband. She also sought a Domestic Exclusion Order (“DEO”), a No-Contact Order (“NCO”) as well as a Stay Away Order (“SAO”) and a Mandatory Treatment Order (“MTO”).

2       I heard the trial of the matter on 15 October 2025. Judgment was reserved. My decision was delivered on 19 December 2025. These are the reasons for my decision.

3       The Wife’s complaint was based on sexual abuse, as well as emotional and/or psychological abuse. She cited a single incident in support of her application.

4       This incident had taken place on 28 May 2025. The Husband had returned, with their two daughters, from a martial arts lesson. After he had left the house, the Wife placed an order for wine. She was alone in her room watching a show on her phone. The wine arrived at 11.15pm. The Wife says she had not eaten properly or slept well in days. She drank to help herself sleep. She said she was emotionally overwhelmed and physically exhausted.

5       As the Wife was enjoying her alone time, the Husband re-entered the house and came into her room. He began to scold her for drinking. The Wife explained, during the trial, that this was because the both of them had agreed not to drink in front of the children, and that was because the consumption of alcohol was also against their religious beliefs.

6       The Wife says that she was lying on her side, facing away from the Husband. He had then come up behind her and hugged her tightly, refusing to let go.

7       The Wife says she asked him repeatedly to stop, but she did not scream as she did not want to scare or traumatise the children. Despite her pleas, the Husband inserted his fingers into her vagina. The Wife begged him to stop. She told him that she would call the police. The Husband then proceeded to rape her as she continued to beg him to stop and “repeatedly said no”.[note: 1] His response to her pleas was: “[i]f you’re going to report, might as well I finish it”.[note: 2]

8       The Wife says that eventually, after she begged him again, he stopped and left the room. She was left “in shock, violated, and emotionally destroyed”.

9       In the wake of this incident, the Wife texted her friend to let her know what had happened. She fell asleep as she was physically and mentally drained. She reported the assault the next morning, and the Investigation Officer advised her to not have direct contact with the Husband. She was also advised to relocate temporarily for her own safety.

10     The Wife described the impact of the assault on her. She said she was deeply affected, and that she fell into depression. She locked herself in her room for days and was unable to function. She said she was “constantly on edge” and that small sudden movements would frighten her, and she was “terrified” of having anyone behind her.

11     I would, at this juncture, note that the documentary evidence produced by both the Wife and Husband was thin. There was, however, a first information report adduced by the Wife showing that she had made a police report at around 9 am on the 29th of May 2025.

12     The Husband did not deny that he had sex with the Wife on 28 May 2025. However, he asserted that it was consensual. This was his account of events.

13     He said that after he had sent the two children home after their martial arts class, he had texted the Wife to inform her that there was a funeral at the void deck.[note: 3] He did this to warn the Wife, who was superstitious, not to be shocked if she heard sudden loud noises or prayers.

14     The Wife replied to ask where he was headed for the night. Upon seeing this text, the Husband assumed that she was afraid. This made him decide to return to the house. He found the Wife drinking. He says that they struck up a conversation, and that they started kissing soon after. According to him, that was how they had begun to have sex.[note: 4]

15     The Husband also testified that he was upset when he discovered that the Wife had been drinking in the house. That said, it was his evidence that he did not scold her for doing so. He had asked her “why you doing this” in what he said was an “advising” or “managerial” tone.[note: 5] He says the Wife did not respond – she just stared blankly into space and held her glass of wine.[note: 6] After this, they began talking about the past, and their current relationships. It was during this time when the Husband said “it sparked”, and by that he meant that they had started kissing and had sex.

16     The Husband’s account was internally inconsistent in that it was puzzling how he had gone from being upset with the Wife over her consumption of alcohol in the house, to a discussion on their shared past, and their conversation led to what he says was the consensual sexual intercourse that followed. By his own account, the issue of consuming alcohol in the house was quite a serious matter. Apart from the fact that it was against their religious beliefs, the Husband explained that it was necessary to demonstrate, to both their children, that drinking was not right and that it was prohibited.

17     In this connection, I cannot see how this conversation on such a serious matter had led to, as the Husband claims, a discussion on their past sex lives and the consensual intercourse that followed. The Husband had also testified that when he walked into the master bedroom, he saw the Wife holding a glass of wine and staring blankly at the wall. He also said that when he had asked her about drinking wine in the house, she had kept quiet.[note: 7] Given the Husband’s evidence as to the state the Wife was in when they had that conversation about the consumption of alcohol, I found his account of events quite difficult to believe – namely that they had gone from a serious conversation on the consumption of alcohol in the house to a state of mutual arousal where they ended up having sex. I found that the narrative the Husband had presented was an attempt to cover up what had actually transpired – that he had forced himself on the Wife in this incident.

18     To sum up, of the two accounts of the events of 28 May 2025 that were presented to me, I found the Wife’s account to be more believable. Her account was internally consistent, and there was documentary evidence to support her version of events – namely, that first incident report on 29 May 2025.

19     Given that I accepted the Wife’s account of events on 28 May 2025, I also found that the Husband’s actions amounted to family violence – that he had committed an act of sexual abuse by forcing the Wife to have sex with him. I also found that the Husband’s actions in forcing the Wife to have sex with him did amount to emotional and/or psychological abuse – it was clear to me that the Wife was tormented and distressed by his actions to the point where she was not only startled or scared by sudden movements behind her, but had also fallen into depression.[note: 8]

20     In addition to this, I also found it necessary to order a PPO for the Wife’s personal safety or protection. The law makes it clear that in considering the necessity of ordering a PPO, the court undertakes a risk assessment: XFL v XFM [2024] SGFC 103 at [19]. I am of the view that there was indeed a high risk of the Husband committing family violence on the Wife.

21     For one, the act of family violence which I found the Husband had committed showed that he had no respect for the Wife’s boundaries. Further, this act had also taken place in the house, when the children were at home. Although there are pending divorce proceedings between the Husband and the Wife, it did appear that the both of them would continue to interact with each other and share a physical space because of their children. That they would likely share a common space, in my judgment, and taking into account the act of family violence the Husband had committed, only pointed to the elevated risk of future family violence being committed on the Wife.

22     The Wife was thus granted a PPO. Having granted the Wife a PPO, I considered that, in light of the act of family violence that had been committed, it was also necessary for her protection or personal safety to grant her a DEO which was limited to the master bedroom of the flat. In addition, I ordered that both the Husband and the Wife attend counselling.

23     As for the other orders that the Wife sought, namely the SAO, NCO, and MTO, I did not find that it was necessary for those orders to be made. For one, there was no evidence put before me which hinted that the Husband suffered from any underlying mental condition that was the cause of the family violence. As for the SAO, the Wife had asked for the Husband to be prevented from coming within a 400m radius of the flat. Having already granted a DEO limited to the master bedroom, I did not find it necessary to order the SAO which the Wife sought. Finally, and in relation to the NCO, having considered the nature of the act of family violence that had been committed and the orders that I had already made, I concluded that it was not necessary to make such an order.

html:
XXG v XXF

XXG v XXF
[2026] SGFC 1

Case Number:SSP 960/2024
Decision Date:13 January 2026
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Soh Kian Peng
Counsel Name(s): Nur Amalina Binte Kamal (IKA Law LLC) for the Sister; The Brother in-person and unrepresented.
Parties: XXG — XXF

Family Law – Personal Protection Order

Family Law – No Contact Order

Family Law – Stay Away Order

13 January 2026

Magistrate Soh Kian Peng:

1       SSP 960 of 2025 (“SSP 960”) was the Sister’s application against her Brother. She applied for a Personal Protection Order (“PPO”), a Stay Away Order (“SAO”) and a No Contact Order (“NCO”).

2       At the trial before me, the Sister was represented by Ms Amalina Kamal (“Ms Amalina”). The Brother was self-represented.

3       I heard the trial and dismissed the Sister’s application. These are the reasons for my decision.

4       To succeed in her application, the provisions of the Women’s Charter 1961 make it clear that she must prove the following two things on a balance of probabilities:

(a)     The first is that the Brother had committed, or was likely to commit, family violence on her.

(b)     The second is that the orders which she had applied for are indeed necessary for her personal safety or protection.

5       The Sister alleges that the Brother had committed family violence on her in the following incidents, which I shall deal with in turn.

6       The first incident occurred on the 18th of April 2025. The background to this incident took place a day earlier. The Sister had received a frantic phone call from her Mother. It transpired that their parents had fought – this resulted in their Father leaving the house in Johor Bahru. The Father did not return. This prompted the Mother to call the Sister.

7       The Sister checked the Father’s location on her mobile phone. However, the Father had disabled the tracking function. The Sister enlisted the help of neighbours in Johor Bahru to locate the Father. It was a sleepless night for her.

8       The next morning, when she attempted to track her Father’s location using the mobile phone application, she discovered that her Father’s last location was at her Brother’s residence. She was enraged that her Father would seek shelter with her Brother knowing full well that the Brother, according to her, was engaging in practices that were contrary to their religious beliefs.

9       She demanded that the Father return to the Johor Bahru home immediately. She sent him a series of harshly worded text messages as can be seen from the excerpt reproduced below:

Time Stamp

Message

8:21 am

What are you doing going back to your son’s house with his slut

8:21 am

Go back now

8:21 am

Don’t make me lose my shit

8:21 am

Get out of that cursed [XX] house now

8:21 am

What is wrong with you

8:21 am

You are going against my mother now

8:21 am

You wanna take shelter with your slut son

8:22 am

So now you’re following his slutty behaviour too

8:22 am

Living together with his slut

8:22 am

Becoming a sinner along with them

8:22 am

Go back now

8:22 am

You wait at home



10     Later that day, in the afternoon, she received a series of video messages. The Brother had sent these video messages using the Father’s WhatsApp account. The Sister says that those video messages were threatening. The Sister produced those video clips as well as the accompanying transcription and translation. The Brother had recorded these video clips and sent them to the Sister. He can be seen scolding the Sister and hurling verbal insults at her.

11     Of the Brother’s entire tirade, the Sister highlighted the two lines in which the Brother had threatened to “slap her face” and that he would do so even if it meant that he would go to jail. The Sister says that this constituted clear evidence of a threat to harm her.

12     When viewed in isolation, there was indeed much force to the argument that the two lines which the Sister had highlighted were threats of harm which would, conceivably, fall under the definition of physical abuse, or emotional and/or psychological abuse as is set out in the Women’s Charter 1961.

13     It must, however, be remembered that when people are caught up in the heat of an argument, they may often utter rather nasty or unpalatable things out of sheer frustration. This was, in my judgment, exactly what had happened in the present case. The Brother had obviously taken offence with what the Sister had said to their Father about him. The Sister had exhibited copies of the messages which she had sent to her Father. In those messages, she had said many unpleasant things about the Brother. Unsurprisingly, the Brother was extremely angry and frustrated with what his Sister had said, which not only insulted him, but also conflicted with his core values. He thus decided to vent his frustration by scolding her. While one might, quite justifiably, rightfully describe his conduct or behaviour as seen in the video recordings as boorish and rude, I do not find that he had committed physical abuse, nor had he, through his actions, inflicted emotional or psychological abuse on the Sister.

14     I turn now to consider the second incident the Sister had complained of. This took place on 1 May 2025.

15     The Sister was with the Mother at the home in Johor Bahru. They had just returned from grocery shopping. They saw the Father’s motorcycle parked outside the house, but he was not in.

16     At about 6.45pm, the Brother appeared at the front gate. He banged violently on the door. He shouted expletives. The Mother went to confront him. The argument escalated.

17     During this time, the Sister recorded the incident. She shouted for help from their neighbours. She said that she was frightened of what the Brother might do.

18     The police were called in, and they arrived on the scene. Statements were taken, and both the Mother and the Sister sought refuge in a neighbour’s house.

19     Given that this incident had taken place in Johor Bahru, there was the preliminary issue of whether the family violence provisions in the Women’s Charter would apply to acts done abroad: see AXK v AXL [2011] SGDC 431 at [14] – [16]. Ms Amalina argued, referencing s 3 of the Women’s Charter 1961, that the relevant provisions applied to people that were either in Singapore, or domiciled in Singapore. Given this, and by extension, once the provisions of the Women’s Charter 1961 applied, acts done abroad could also be taken into account.

20     I did not need to decide on this point. That was because I did not find that the Brother had committed an act of FV in this incident on 1 May 2025.

21     Recordings of the incident were produced. These recordings and the accompanying transcript show that there was a heated argument that had taken place. The Brother was exchanging salvoes with the Mother and the Sister. The Sister’s behaviour during this entire incident is telling. She did not appear to be frightened of the Brother. She was, after all, more than capable of retorting with her own barbed comments which were squarely aimed at the Brother.

22     Further, while the transcript did show that the Brother had, once again, threatened the Sister, it cannot be cited as an instance of the Brother inflicting family violence on her. The Brother was clearly responding to the Sister’s taunts about him being afraid of the police.

23     I come now to the third incident which took place two days after the incident on 1 May 2025. The Sister was performing her duties as a Polling Officer. She says that the Brother had turned up at the polling booth that she had been assigned to. She says that he approached her booth and mocked her, saying: “eh what, not working ah”. She says that she froze and drew closer to her fellow Polling Officer for support. The Sister did not acknowledge the Brother. After the Brother voted, he left on his motorbike, and revved his engine as he left.

24     I did not find that the Brother’s actions in this incident on 3 May 2025 fell within the definitions of family violence. It was a brief encounter between the siblings, and in my judgment, the Brother had merely tried to strike up a conversation with the Sister, notwithstanding the unpleasant quarrel they had had a few days prior. Although the Sister claimed that she was terrified of the Brother in this incident on 3 May 2025, because of the trauma she had suffered in the incident on 1 May 2025 – I found this to be an exaggeration. As I have mentioned, the videos of the 1st May 2025 incident clearly showed that the Sister was able to return verbal salvoes of her own, and indeed, had even taunted the Brother. She was not some helpless victim cowering in fear before the Brother.

25     I would add that even when I considered all the incidents complained of in totality, I did not find that the Brother had committed family violence on the Sister. The evidence did not show a continued and sustained campaign of harassment against the Sister. Rather, these incidents marked the increasingly frayed relations between the Brother and the Sister.

26     For completeness, I also did not find that the Brother was likely to commit family violence on the Sister. The evidence before me only went so far as to show that the Brother would only react when provoked by the Sister. There was nothing before me to suggest that the Brother had a vindictive streak about him. Therefore, while one may conclude that the Brother may indeed have strained relations with the Sister, and that he might hold a grudge, there was nothing to suggest that he would act on this.

27     In short, I did not find that the Sister had proven that the Brother had committed family violence on her, or that he was likely to commit family violence on her. The result is that the Sister’s application for a PPO must fail.

28     In any event, I did not find it necessary to grant a PPO for the Sister’s personal safety or protection.

29     In assessing the necessity of granting a PPO, the court essentially undertakes a risk assessment as to the likelihood of family violence being committed in the future. I found that there was a low risk of the Brother committing family violence on the Sister. For one, the Sister appears to have cut off all ties with the Brother. She was not living with him, and she had completely blocked him over messaging apps and social media. This degree of separation between herself and the Brother thus minimises the opportunity for further interaction, and with it, further opportunities for conflict.

30     The Sister’s application for a PPO was dismissed. It followed, as a result, that her application for a Stay-Away Order (“SAO”) and a No-Contact-Order (“NCO”) must also fail.

XXO v XXP

XXO v XXP
[2026] SGFC 5

Case Number:FC/OADV 361 of 2025, MSS 1591 of 2025
Decision Date:06 January 2026
Tribunal/Court:Family Court
Coram: Kow Keng Siong
Counsel Name(s): Muhammad Hasif bin Abdul Aziz (M/s A.W. Law LLC) for the Father; Mother in person.
Parties: XXO — XXP

Family Law – Maintenance – Child – Ex-husband applying to vary child maintenance

Family Law – Maintenance – Child – Ex-wife applying to enforce maintenance order – Ex-husband could afford to pay maintenance but had chosen not to breach maintenance order

6 January 2026

District Judge Kow Keng Siong:

Introduction

1       This case concerns a dispute regarding a child’s maintenance. The child was born in February 2016 (“the Child”). The parents are divorced. The Father has applied to vary child maintenance (FC/OADV 361/2025) while the Mother has applied to enforce the payment of maintenance arrears (MSS 1591 of 2025).

2       These are the background facts.

The 2023 Order

3       By an order made in October 2023 (FC/ORC 4893/2023) (“2023 Order”), the Father was required to pay the Mother a total of $4,000/month in maintenance consisting of the following.

 

Nature of payment

(a)

$2,300/month

(b)

Backdated child maintenance

Note.

(1) The payments of $1,700/month were to last for 26 months commencing from 31 October 2023.

(2) On the 27th month (i.e., 31 December 2025), there was to be a final payment of $1,800.

(3) These payments were to discharge backdated child maintenance which came to a total of $46,000 at the material time: 2023 Order at clause 3(b).

$1,700/month



The breach

4       The Father has not fully complied with the 2023 Order. The arrears in payable and backdated child maintenance from October 2023 to the date of this judgment (6 January 2026) amount to a total of $38,100 (“Arrears”).

The applications

5       The Mother seeks to enforce the payment of the Arrears – either (a) in one lump sum or (b) in three monthly instalments. She requests that the enforcement be done by an attachment of earnings order (“AEO”). (“Enforcement Application”)

6       On the other hand, the Father applies (a) to pay the Arrears by instalments of $1,700/month (“Instalment Application”) and (b) to reduce the payable child maintenance from $2,300/month to $1,200/month prospectively (“Variation Application”).

Variation Application

7       I begin with the Variation Application.

Applicable principles

8       Under s 118 of the Women’s Charter 1961 (“Charter”), an applicant seeking to vary a maintenance order must prove (a) a material change of circumstances (“Requirement 1”), (b) occurring after the order (“Requirement 2”), and (c) that it is necessary and fair to vary the order (“Requirement 3”): BZD v BZE [2020] SGCA 1 at [10] and [14].

9       In assessing whether Requirement 3 is met, the following are relevant.

(a)     What are the Child’s reasonable monthly expenses?

(b)     Given that both parents have a legal duty to contribute to the maintenance of their child (s 68 of the Charter), what will be the Father’s share towards the child’s maintenance if her expenses are to be apportioned between both parents based on their relative monthly incomes?

(c)     Whether the Father can meet his share having regard to his reasonable expenses and disposable income.

Requirements 1 and 2 – Material change after the 2023 Order

10     In this case, I find that Requirements 1 and 2 have been met as there has been a significant reduction in the Father’s income after the 2023 Order.[note: 1]

(a)     In October 2023 (when the order was issued), the Father’s net income was $23,840/month.

(b)     In May 2024, he was terminated and remained unemployed for about six months. In December 2024, the Father secured employment in the United Kingdom (“UK”) at the following lower income.

Note.

The Father’s target bonus is 10%, lower than the 25% under his previous employment.[note: 2]



Requirement 3 – Necessary and fair

11     Next, I assess whether that it is necessary and fair to vary the 2023 Order.

Child’s reasonable monthly expenses

(A)    Undisputed expenses

(B)    Food, groceries, etc

13     The Mother contends that the payable maintenance should also cover the Child’s food outside school (see in [12(g)]), groceries, insurance and medical expenses. She however did not quantify these items and provided no supporting documents.

14     The Father accepts that it is reasonable to include such expenses. He invites the Court to determine an appropriate amount.[note: 11]

15     Taking a broad-brush approach, I assess the expenses for these items at $900/month taking into account (a) the parties’ likely living standards as reflected in their combined income (about $24,000/month); (b) the Child’s age (about nine); and (c) the Father’s own estimate of these very items at $900/month (see below).[note: 12]

17     I decline to include these items in the computation of the Child’s expenses. As the Father rightly points out, the Mother would, in any event, need to secure housing for herself. Further, I am of the view that to load a share of her mortgage onto “child maintenance” would in effect be requiring the Father to subsidise her acquisition of a capital asset. I do not think this is fair.

(D)    Total expenses

18     To sum-up, I assess the Child’s reasonable expenses at $2,300/month (being $1,400/month + $900/month).

Father’s share

19     I next consider what would be the Father’s share of these expenses if they are to be apportioned based on the parents’ relative monthly incomes. In this regard, I note the following.

(a)     The Father’s current income is about $18,000/month.

(b)     The Mother is an insurance agent. Her income fluctuates depending on the commissions that she receives. According to the Mother, her income has dropped in 2025. In the circumstance, I take the income of the most current period before me – i.e., January to August 2025. I arrive at an average income of about $6,000/month.

20     Based on their relative incomes, the parties’ share of the Child’s expenses will be as follows.

Can the Father afford $1,700/month

21     In my view, the Father can afford to pay $1,700/month towards the Child’s maintenance. I come to this view based on the following.

22      First, the Father’s reasonable expenses (including taxes and compulsory deductions) are $14,711/month. The details are set out below.

23      Second, based on a gross income of about $18,069.11/month, less his expenses ($14,711/month), the Father’s disposable income is about $3,358.11/month. A contribution of $1,700/month towards the Child’s maintenance is clearly within his means.

Can the Mother afford $600/month

24     In my view, the Mother can afford to contribute $600/month towards the Child’s maintenance. This amount constitutes only 10% of her income ($6,000/month). Taking into account her mortgage ($2,135/month) and her share of maintenance ($600/month), she still retains $3,265/month for her other expenses.

Order on Variation Application

25     I therefore vary clause 3(a) of the 2023 Order as follows.

The Father shall pay the Mother $1,700/month as payable child maintenance from 31 January 2026,[note: 23] and thereafter on the last day of each month, into the Mother’s designated account.

Enforcement and the Arrears

26     Finally, I turn to the Enforcement Application.

27     Under the 2023 Order, the Father had 27 months from October 2023 to discharge the backdated child maintenance by way of monthly instalments. Based on the instalment schedule, the last payment for the backdated child maintenance is December 2025. In other words, if the Father had complied with the schedule, the backdated child maintenance would have been completely discharged by the time of this judgement.

28     Regrettably, the Father did not comply. The issue which thus arises is this – What is the most effective way to enforce the payment of the Arrears?

Further instalment payments untenable

29     The Father seeks another opportunity to settle his outstanding maintenance payments by instalments.

30     I reject this request. It is very clear that the Father has a poor track record in complying with a maintenance order. He has repeatedly failed to keep up with his maintenance payments even during periods when he had substantial means.

(a)     Before October 2023, while earning a very high income of $23,840/month, the Father had accumulated $46,000 of backdated child maintenance. This is reflected in the 2023 Order at clause 3(b).

(b)     Even after the 2023 Order gave him a structured instalment plan, the Father continued to default on his maintenance payments for the first three months (October to December 2023). During the trial, he did not provide any explanation for this default.

(c)     Between August 2024 to July 2025, the Father failed to make full payment despite having received –

(i)       An ex-gratia payment of $150,649.05 in April 2024 (when he was retrenched).

(ii)       Income of about $18,000/month from December 2024.

(iii)       Rental income of $1,500/month from January 2025 to at least August 2025 for some months.[note: 24]

(d)     During the same default period, between August 2024 to June 2025, the Father had instead chosen to pay $15,260.04 for an MBA course.[note: 25] Again, he did not provide any satisfactory explanation as to why he did not prioritise his obligation to pay child maintenance.

AEO is inappropriate

31     Having found it untenable to allow the Father to discharge the Arrears by way of instalment payments, I turn to the Mother’s request for an AEO.

32     After careful consideration, I decided against making the order. This is because an AEO is unlikely to be an effective enforcement tool in the present case. Let me explain.

(a)     The power to issue an AEO is provided under s 81 of the Charter. It is directed to a respondent’s employer and depends for its efficacy on two things. First, the employer’s ability to comply with the duties imposed by the order and the Charter: s 84, s 85(1)(b) and s 86(c). Second, the Court’s ability to take appropriate actions if the employer fails to comply. In this case, the Father’s employer is in the UK and is thus outside the legal and practical reach of our jurisdiction.

(b)     Further, and in any event, it is unclear whether the Father will continue to work for his current UK employer for the long term. This is because since September 2025, he has been based in Singapore and there is evidence to suggest that he may be seeking alternative employment. (There is a WhatsApp message from him showing that he had a job interview in November 2025.)

Father can pay

33     In determining the appropriate enforcement tool, I note that the Father can in fact afford to pay the Arrears.

(a)      First, as of May 2025, he had funds amounting to $93,286.52 in his savings account.[note: 26] (The Father did not disclose more recent information regarding the funds in the account.) During the trial, he did not take the position that the funds are no longer available. Neither did he show good reasons as to why the funds should not be used to discharge the Arrears. It bears noting that he had ample opportunities to raise such issues at the trial.[note: 27]

(b)      Second, the Father has a 3-bedroom private apartment in Singapore. He can rent out one of its rooms should he need additional funds. After all, he had done so in 2025 and secured rental income at $1,500/month.[note: 28]

(c)      Third, and for completeness, his private apartment was valued in 2023 at $1,700,000. It had an outstanding mortgage of $696,369.60 at the material time. In other words, the Father has an asset with a net value of about $1,000,000.

Imprisonment is appropriate

34     Given that the Father has the means to pay the Arrears, I decide to give him one final opportunity to do so. If he fails to seize on this opportunity, then imprisonment under s 71(1)(b) of the Charter will follow. A threat of imprisonment can be a very powerful deterrent for a maintenance defaulter who is able – but is unwilling – to pay maintenance: XFB v XFX [2024] SGFC 100 at footnote 6.

35     In my view, 14 days will be a proportionate response to his maintenance default and to incentivise him to pay the Arrears. In coming to this view, I have considered that (a) this is a case of a parent not taking his duty to pay maintenance seriously (as opposed to one where the default was to cause hardship to the child and the care-parent), (b) the duration of the default is relatively long (some of the payments have been outstanding for more than two years), (c) the Father did make some payments during the default period, (d) this is his first enforcement action, (e) the Arrears are of a relatively significant value, and (f) there is no evidence that the Child and Mother has suffered serious hardship because of the default in maintenance.

Order on enforcement

36     Accordingly, in relation to MSS 1591 of 2025 –

(a)     I grant the Father a final extension of time to pay the arrears for the payable and backdated child maintenance from October 2023 to 6 January 2026 (totalling $38,100) into the Mother's designated account. He is to do so in four weeks’ time, i.e., by 3 February 2026 (“due date”). (Note. This is consistent with the Mother’s request for the Arrears to be paid in one lump sum.)

(b)     If the Father fails to pay the Arrears by the due date, then –

(i)       Pursuant to s 71(1)(b) of the Charter, I order that he shall serve 14 days’ imprisonment.

(ii)       The sentence shall commence on 6 February 2026.

(iii)       The Father shall surrender himself to Court 1A of the Family Justice Courts at 12 pm on 6 February 2026 to commence his sentence.

Clause 3(b)

37     For completeness, I note that clause 3(b) of the 2023 Order states that –

The [Father] will pay to the [Mother] backdated maintenance of $46,000. This will be repaid to the [Mother] as an additional $1,700.00 per month for the next twenty-six (26) months, with a final payment of $1,800.00 on the 27th month, from 31 October 2023, and thereafter on the last day of each month. Payment will be made into the [Mother's] designated account.

[text in square brackets added]

38     When my decision was announced, the Father’s counsel sought clarification as to whether the payment schedule in clause 3(b) would need to be varied. On reflection, the answer is No. As stated in [27] above, by the time of this judgement, the schedule as already lapsed.

Conclusion

39     For the above reasons –

(a)     The Father’s Variation Application in FC/OADV 361 of 2025 is allowed to the extent in [25] above.

(b)     The Mother’s Enforcement Application in MSS 1591 of 2025 is allowed to the extent in [36] above.
